siteMetadata.title: Apollo GraphQL Docs
siteMetadata.description: A guide to using Apollo Server

frontmatter.title: Plugins
frontmatter.description: Extend Apollo Server with custom functionality

children.value: Plugins are available in Apollo Server 2.2.x and later.

enable you to extend Apollo Server's core functionality by performing
custom operations in response to certain events. Currently, these events correspond
to individual phases of the GraphQL request lifecycle, and to the startup of Apollo Server itself.

For example, a basic logging plugin might log the GraphQL query string associated
with each request that's sent to Apollo Server.

Plugins are JavaScript objects that implement one or more functions that respond to
events. Here's a basic plugin that responds to the
If you're using TypeScript to create a plugin, the

You can define a plugin in the same file where you initialize Apollo Server, or
you can export it as a separate module:
To create a plugin that accepts options, create a function that accepts an
object and returns a properly structured plugin object, like so:

it responds to by implementing functions that correspond to those events.
The plugin in the examples above responds to the

event, which
fires when Apollo Server is preparing to start up.
A plugin can respond to any combination of supported events.

properties.ariaLabel: responding to request lifecycle events permalink

children.value:
Plugins can respond to the following events associated with the GraphQL request

event fires whenever Apollo Server receives a GraphQL request,

any of the lifecycle events listed above. You can respond to this event
just like you respond to

use this function
to define responses for a request's lifecycle events, like so:

function can optionally return an object that
defines functions that respond to request lifecycle events. This structure
organizes and encapsulates all of your plugin's request lifecycle logic, making it
easier to reason about.
The following diagram illustrates the sequence of events that fire for each request. Each of these events is documented
Any event below that can result in "Success" can also result in an error. Whenever an error occurs, the
event fires and the remainder of the "Success" path does

that are called when their associated step

Event handlers for the following events can optionally return a function
that is invoked after the corresponding lifecycle phase

are passed any errors that occurred during the
execution of that lifecycle phase. For example, the following plugin logs
any errors that occur during any of the above lifecycle events:
// This end hook is unique in that it can receive an array of errors,
// which will contain every validation error that occurred.

of errors that
contains every validation error that occurred (if any). The

end hook receives the error thrown by the resolver as the first argument and the result of the resolver as the second argument. The arguments to each
end hook are documented in the type definitions in

properties.ariaLabel: inspecting request and response details permalink

children.value: and request lifecycle functions accept a
parameter. This parameter is of type
These types and their related subtypes are all defined in
Add your plugin to Apollo Server by providing a

/* This example doesn't provide `typeDefs` or `resolvers`,
   both of which are required to start the server. */
// You can import plugins or define them in-line, as shown:
/* This plugin is from a package that's imported above. */
Apollo Server fires two types of events that plugins can hook into:

Server lifecycle events are high-level events related to the lifecycle of Apollo Server itself.
Currently, two server lifecycle events are supported:
Request lifecycle events are associated with a specific request. You define responses to these events
event fires when Apollo Server is preparing to start serving GraphQL requests. If you respond to this event with an
function (or if the function returns a
), the server doesn't start until the asynchronous operation completes. If the

). This helps you make sure all
of your server's dependencies are available before attempting to begin serving requests.
event fires when Apollo Server is starting to shut down because
has been invoked (either explicitly by your code, or by one of the
). If your plugin is running any background tasks, this is a good place to shut them down.
handler in the object returned by your
handler, because the two handlers usually interact with the same data. Currently,
handlers do not take arguments (this might change in the future).
event fires whenever Apollo Server begins fulfilling a GraphQL request.

This function can optionally return an object that includes functions for responding
to request lifecycle events that might follow

/* Within this returned object, define functions that respond
           to request-specific lifecycle events. */
If your plugin doesn't need to respond to any request lifecycle events,
If you're using TypeScript to create your plugin, implement the
module to define functions for request lifecycle events.
event is invoked after Apollo Server has determined the

-representation of the incoming operation that it will act upon.  In the
event that this

was not directly passed in from the client, this
may be retrieved from a cache store (e.g., Automated Persisted Queries).
At this stage, there is not a guarantee that the operation is not malformed.

event fires whenever Apollo Server will parse a GraphQL
request to create its associated
If Apollo Server receives a request with a query string that matches a

might already be available in Apollo Server's cache.
In this case,

called for the request, because parsing
does not occur.

event fires whenever Apollo Server will validate a
request's

is
already available in Apollo Server's cache (only successfully validated
s are cached by Apollo Server).

AST is guaranteed to be
available at this stage, because parsing must succeed for validation to occur.

library successfully
determines the operation to execute from a request's

AST. At this stage,
both the
. When this event fires, your resolvers have not yet executed (they execute after
If the operation is anonymous (i.e., the operation is

event is fired immediately before GraphQL execution
would take place. If its return value resolves to a non-null

,
that result is used instead of executing the query. Hooks from different plugins
are invoked in series, and the first non-null response is used.

event fires whenever Apollo Server begins executing the
GraphQL operation specified by a request's
function. Alternatively, it may return an object with one or both of the methods
is treated identically to an end hook: it is called after execution with any errors that occurred.
is documented in the next section.
event fires whenever Apollo Server is about to resolve a single field during the execution of an operation. The handler is passed an object with four fields (
four positional arguments passed to resolvers
corresponds to the argument often called
handler in the object returned by your
function that's invoked with the resolver's result (or the error that it throws). The end hook is called when your resolver has
resolved (e.g., if the resolver returns a Promise, the hook is called with the Promise's eventual resolved result).

event fires when Apollo Server encounters errors while
parsing, validating, or executing a GraphQL operation.

event fires whenever Apollo Server is about to send a response
for a GraphQL operation. This event fires (and Apollo Server sends a response) even
if the GraphQL operation encounters one or more errors.
